sn8.8:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ aḍḍhatelasehi bhikkhusatehi.
sn8.8:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery, together with a large Saṅgha of 1,250 mendicants.

sn8.8:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā bhikkhū nibbānapaṭisaṃyuttāya dhammiyā kathāya sandasseti samādapeti samuttejeti sampahaṃseti.
sn8.8:1.2.eng: Now at that time the Buddha was educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the mendicants with a Dhamma talk about extinguishment.

sn8.8:1.3.pli: Te ca bhikkhū aṭṭhiṃ katvā manasi katvā sabbacetasā samannāharitvā ohitasotā dhammaṃ suṇanti.
sn8.8:1.3.eng: And those mendicants were paying attention, applying the mind, concentrating wholeheartedly, and actively listening.

sn8.8:1.5.pli: “ayaṃ kho bhagavā bhikkhū nibbānapaṭisaṃyuttāya dhammiyā kathāya sandasseti samādapeti samuttejeti sampahaṃseti.
sn8.8:1.5.eng: “The Buddha is educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the mendicants with a Dhamma talk about extinguishment.

sn8.8:1.6.pli: Te ca bhikkhū aṭṭhiṃ katvā manasi katvā sabbacetasā samannāharitvā ohitasotā dhammaṃ suṇanti.
sn8.8:1.6.eng: And those mendicants are paying attention, applying the mind, concentrating wholeheartedly, and actively listening.

sn8.8:1.7.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ bhagavantaṃ sammukhā sāruppāhi gāthāhi abhitthaveyyan”ti.
sn8.8:1.7.eng: Why don’t I extoll him in his presence with fitting verses?”

sn8.8:2.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā vaṅgīso uṭṭhāyāsanā ekaṃsaṃ uttarāsaṅgaṃ karitvā yena bhagavā tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn8.8:2.1.eng: Then Venerable Vaṅgīsa got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and said,

sn8.8:2.2.eng: “I feel inspired to speak, Blessed One! I feel inspired to speak, Holy One!”

sn8.8:2.3.eng: “Then speak as you feel inspired,” said the Buddha.

sn8.8:2.4.pli: Atha kho āyasmā vaṅgīso bhagavantaṃ sammukhā sāruppāhi gāthāhi abhitthavi:
sn8.8:2.4.eng: Then Vaṅgīsa extolled the Buddha in his presence with fitting verses:

sn8.8:3.3.eng: as he teaches the immaculate Dhamma,

sn8.8:3.4.eng: extinguishment, fearing nothing from any quarter.

sn8.8:4.1.eng: They listen to the immaculate Dhamma

sn8.8:4.2.eng: taught by the fully awakened Buddha;

sn8.8:4.4.eng: at the fore of the mendicant Saṅgha,

sn8.8:5.2.comm: The idea of the seven seers, long proverbial in Vedic culture, was adapted for Gotama in DN 14, where he is the seventh recorded Buddha in the lineage starting with Vipassī. Various texts and commentaries also allow the sense, “best of seers”.

sn8.8:5.3.eng: You are like a great cloud

sn8.8:5.4.comm: In a cold northern climate this sounds unappealing, but in the heat the generous rain is a cool blessing.

sn8.8:6.2.eng: out of desire to see the teacher.

sn8.8:7.1.pli: “Kiṃ nu te, vaṅgīsa, imā gāthāyo pubbe parivitakkitā, udāhu ṭhānasova taṃ paṭibhantī”ti?
sn8.8:7.1.eng: “Vaṅgīsa, had you previously composed these verses, or did they spring to mind in the moment?”

sn8.8:7.2.pli: “Na kho me, bhante, imā gāthāyo pubbe parivitakkitā, atha kho ṭhānasova maṃ paṭibhantī”ti.
sn8.8:7.2.eng: “They sprang to mind in the moment, sir.”

sn8.8:7.3.pli: “Tena hi taṃ, vaṅgīsa, bhiyyoso mattāya pubbe aparivitakkitā gāthāyo paṭibhantū”ti.
sn8.8:7.3.eng: “Well then, Vaṅgīsa, speak some more spontaneously inspired verses.”

sn8.8:7.4.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā vaṅgīso bhagavato paṭissutvā bhiyyoso mattāya bhagavantaṃ pubbe aparivitakkitāhi gāthāhi abhitthavi:
sn8.8:7.4.eng: “Yes, sir,” replied Vaṅgīsa. Then he extolled the Buddha with some more spontaneously inspired verses, not previously composed:

sn8.8:8.1.comm: The “wrong path” (ummagga) is one that takes you to the wrong destination (MN 107:14.26).

sn8.8:8.3.eng: See him, the liberator from bonds,
sn8.8:8.3.comm: Here Vaṅgīsa turns to address the monks directly.

sn8.8:8.4.eng: dissecting the unattached section by section.
sn8.8:8.4.comm: For asitaṁ bhāgaso pavibhajaṁ, compare the similar phrase vibhatto bhāgaso mito, which refers to the neatly ordered sections of hell (MN 130:16.4) or the suburbs (Snp 2.7:23.2). Vaṅgīsa is referring to the Buddha’s skill in breaking down complex or obscure matters and presenting them systematically.

sn8.8:9.1.eng: You have explained in many ways

sn8.8:9.2.eng: the path to cross the flood.

sn8.8:9.3.eng: The Seers of Truth stand unfaltering
sn8.8:9.3.comm: For this couplet I follow Bodhi’s note in Connected Discourses.

sn8.8:9.4.eng: in the freedom from death explained by you.

sn8.8:10.1.eng: As the bringer of light who has pierced the truth,

sn8.8:10.2.eng: you’ve seen what lies beyond all planes.
sn8.8:10.2.comm: Ṭhiti is viññāṇaṭṭhiti (“planes of consciousness”), i.e. seven realms in which consciousness can be reborn (AN 7.44, DN 15:33.1, DN 33:1.8.11). This is a subtle allusion to the Buddha’s practice under his former teacher Āḷāra Kālāma, where he learned up to the highest “plane of consciousness”, namely the dimension of nothingness. In Snp 5.15:3.1 he speaks of how he understood that attainment and went beyond it. | Not to be confused with the four “grounds for consciousness”, i.e. the first four aggregates, as insight does not consist in going beyond these to consciousness (DN 33:1.11.122, SN 22.54:1.11).

sn8.8:10.3.eng: When you saw and realized this for yourself,

sn8.8:10.4.eng: you taught it first to the group of five.
sn8.8:10.4.comm: Vaṅgīsa continues to invoke the Buddha’s life story by alluding to the first teaching, Rolling Forth the Wheel of Dhamma (SN 56.11). After leaving behind those who taught rebirth in the “planes of consciousness”, the Buddha realized Awakening and proceeded to Varanasi to teach the group of five. This anticipates the next discourse, which features one of the five.

sn8.8:11.1.eng: When the Dhamma has been so well taught,

sn8.8:11.2.eng: how could those who know it be negligent?

sn8.8:11.3.eng: That’s why, being diligent, we should always train

sn8.9:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
sn8.9:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

sn8.9:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā aññāsikoṇḍañño sucirasseva yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavato pādesu sirasā nipatitvā bhagavato pādāni mukhena ca paricumbati, pāṇīhi ca parisambāhati, nāmañca sāveti:
sn8.9:1.2.eng: Then Venerable Koṇḍañña Who Understood approached the Buddha after a very long absence. He bowed with his head at the Buddha’s feet, caressing them and covering them with kisses, and pronounced his name:
sn8.9:1.2.comm: Koṇḍañña gained his nickname as he was the first person to realize the Dhamma after the Buddha (SN 56.11:14.3). His absence was due to his love of solitude, as expressed in his verses (Thag 15.1:0.4). Due to this, he features rarely in the early texts, but the Buddha once saw him meditating (Ud 7.6), and praised him as the senior mendicant (AN 1.188:1.1).

sn8.9:1.3.eng: “I am Koṇḍañña, Blessed One! I am Koṇḍañña, Holy One!”

sn8.9:1.5.pli: “ayaṃ kho āyasmā aññāsikoṇḍañño sucirasseva yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavato pādesu sirasā nipatitvā bhagavato pādāni mukhena ca paricumbati, pāṇīhi ca parisambāhati, nāmañca sāveti:
sn8.9:1.5.eng: “This Venerable Koṇḍañña Who Understood has approached the Buddha after a very long absence. He bowed with his head at the Buddha’s feet, caressing them and covering them with kisses, and pronounced his name:

sn8.9:1.6.eng: ‘I am Koṇḍañña, Blessed One! I am Koṇḍañña, Holy One!’

sn8.9:1.7.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ āyasmantaṃ aññāsikoṇḍaññaṃ bhagavato sammukhā sāruppāhi gāthāhi abhitthaveyyan”ti.
sn8.9:1.7.eng: Why don’t I extoll him in the Buddha’s presence with fitting verses?”

sn8.9:2.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā vaṅgīso uṭṭhāyāsanā ekaṃsaṃ uttarāsaṅgaṃ karitvā yena bhagavā tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn8.9:2.1.eng: Then Venerable Vaṅgīsa got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and said,

sn8.9:2.2.eng: “I feel inspired to speak, Blessed One! I feel inspired to speak, Holy One!”

sn8.9:2.3.eng: “Then speak as you feel inspired,” said the Buddha.

sn8.9:2.4.pli: Atha kho āyasmā vaṅgīso āyasmantaṃ aññāsikoṇḍaññaṃ bhagavato sammukhā sāruppāhi gāthāhi abhitthavi:
sn8.9:2.4.eng: Then Vaṅgīsa extolled Koṇḍañña in the Buddha’s presence with fitting verses:

sn8.9:3.1.eng: “The senior monk awakened after the Buddha,
sn8.9:3.1.comm: Used more generally of early disciples at SN 16.5:5.3.

sn8.9:3.4.comm: Not the three consisting of body, mind, and attachments, for this is only found in later texts (Mnd 2:11.2). Perhaps the three consisting of ethics, view, and ending of defilements (AN 3.93:5.1). But since the absorptions are often called “blissful meditations” (SN 21.4:3.3) and “seclusion” (MN 64:9.2), it’s more satisfying to read the two phrases together.

sn8.9:4.1.eng: Whatever can be attained by a disciple

sn8.9:5.1.eng: With great power and the three knowledges,

sn8.9:5.2.eng: expert in encompassing the minds of others,

sn8.9:5.3.eng: Koṇḍañña, the heir to the Buddha,

sn9.1:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ aññataro bhikkhu kosalesu viharati aññatarasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe.
sn9.1:1.2.eng: At one time one of the mendicants was staying in the land of the Kosalans in a certain forest grove.

sn9.1:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena so bhikkhu divāvihāragato pāpake akusale vitakke vitakketi gehanissite.
sn9.1:1.3.eng: Now at that time that mendicant, during their day’s meditation, was thinking bad, unskillful thoughts to do with the domestic life.

sn9.1:1.4.pli: Atha kho yā tasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe adhivatthā devatā tassa bhikkhuno anukampikā atthakāmā taṃ bhikkhuṃ saṃvejetukāmā yena so bhikkhu tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā taṃ bhikkhuṃ gāthāhi ajjhabhāsi:
sn9.1:1.4.eng: The deity haunting that forest had sympathy for that mendicant, and wanted what’s best for them. So they approached that mendicant wanting to stir them up, and addressed them in verse:

sn9.1:2.2.eng: yet your mind strays to outward things.

sn9.1:2.3.eng: As a person, dispel the desire for people;

sn9.1:2.4.eng: then you’ll be happy, free of greed.

sn9.1:3.1.comm: This verse is particularly tricky; see Bodhi’s note in Connected Discourses for discussion and other interpretations. | Pajahāsi and bhavāsi are reflexive second person singular imperative (= pajaha, bhava).

sn9.1:3.2.eng: let us remind you to be mindful.
sn9.1:3.2.comm: Sārayāmase is reflexive first person plural imperative causative (= sārayāma). The deity is using the “royal we”. | I take taṁ as accusative (“you”) and sataṁ as accusative of purpose (“for the purpose of being mindful”).

sn9.1:3.3.eng: The dusty abyss is so hard to cross;

sn9.1:3.4.eng: don’t let sensual dust drag you down.

sn9.1:4.1.eng: Just as a bird strewn with dirt

sn9.1:4.2.eng: sheds that clingy dust with a shake;

sn9.1:4.3.eng: so too, an energetic, mindful mendicant

sn9.1:4.4.eng: sheds that clingy dust with a shake.”

sn9.1:5.1.pli: Atha kho so bhikkhu tāya devatāya saṃvejito saṃvegamāpādīti.
sn9.1:5.1.eng: Impelled by that deity, that mendicant was struck with a sense of urgency.

sn9.10:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ aññataro bhikkhu kosalesu viharati aññatarasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe.
sn9.10:1.1.eng: At one time one of the mendicants was staying in the land of the Kosalans in a certain forest grove.

sn9.10:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena so bhikkhu yaṃ sudaṃ pubbe ativelaṃ sajjhāyabahulo viharati so aparena samayena appossukko tuṇhībhūto saṅkasāyati.
sn9.10:1.2.eng: Now at that time that mendicant had previously been spending too much time rehearsing. But some time later they adhered to passivity and silence.
sn9.10:1.2.comm: The verb saṅkasāyati is a synonym of allīyati, to stick or adhere to (Kd 3:1.2.3).

sn9.10:1.3.pli: Atha kho yā tasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe adhivatthā devatā tassa bhikkhuno dhammaṃ asuṇantī yena so bhikkhu tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā taṃ bhikkhuṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn9.10:1.3.eng: Not hearing the teaching, the deity haunting that forest approached that mendicant, and addressed them in verse:

sn9.10:2.1.eng: “Mendicant, why don’t you recite <j>passages of the teaching,
sn9.10:2.1.comm: At AN 4.191:1.7, dhammapada refers to all nine categories of the teaching, and I think it has the same sense here.

sn9.10:2.3.eng: Hearing the teaching, one garners confidence;

sn9.10:2.4.eng: and in this very life, one garners praise.”

sn9.10:3.1.eng: “I used to be zealous for <j>passages of the teaching,
sn9.10:3.1.comm: The sense of this unusual five-line verse is not entirely clear to me, and I suspect it is corrupt.

sn9.10:3.4.pli: Yaṃ kiñci diṭṭhaṃva sutaṃ mutaṃ vā;
sn9.10:3.4.eng: whatever was seen, heard, and thought,

sn9.10:3.5.eng: this, good people say, <j>is the laying down by complete understanding.”

sn9.11:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ aññataro bhikkhu kosalesu viharati aññatarasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe.
sn9.11:1.1.eng: At one time one of the mendicants was staying in the land of the Kosalans in a certain forest grove.
sn9.11:1.1.comm: This short discourse offers a concise version of meditation advice given in more detail at MN 19.

sn9.11:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena so bhikkhu divāvihāragato pāpake akusale vitakke vitakketi, seyyathidaṃ—
sn9.11:1.2.eng: Now at that time that mendicant, during their day’s meditation, was thinking bad, unskillful thoughts, that is,
sn9.11:1.2.comm: Even ascetics in the forest can be consumed by bad thoughts.

sn9.11:1.4.pli: Atha kho yā tasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe adhivatthā devatā tassa bhikkhuno anukampikā atthakāmā taṃ bhikkhuṃ saṃvejetukāmā yena so bhikkhu tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā taṃ bhikkhuṃ gāthāhi ajjhabhāsi:
sn9.11:1.4.eng: The deity haunting that forest had sympathy for that mendicant, and wanted what’s best for them. So they approached that mendicant wanting to stir them up, and addressed them in verse:
sn9.11:1.4.comm: Trapped in a spiral of unwholesome thoughts, a meditator may feel guilty or worthless. But the deity has only compassion.

sn9.11:2.1.comm: This term has already appeared at SN 4.4:2.1, and plays a key role in dependent origination (SN 12.4:2.3). Their thoughts are irrational because they lead to the opposite of their goal, freedom.

sn9.11:2.4.eng: make sure your thoughts are rational.

sn9.11:3.1.eng: Thinking about the Teacher, the teaching,
sn9.11:3.1.comm: Unwholesome thoughts are replaced by wholesome ones (cf. MN 20:3.1). The meditator is not urged to stop thinking; quietness is a process.

sn9.11:3.2.eng: the Saṅgha, and your own ethics,

sn9.11:3.4.eng: and rapture and bliss as well, no doubt.

sn9.11:3.5.eng: And when you’re full of joy,
sn9.11:3.5.comm: Suffering spurs on the practice, but the path itself is characterized by joy.

sn9.11:3.6.eng: you’ll make an end to suffering.”

sn9.11:4.1.pli: Atha kho so bhikkhu tāya devatāya saṃvejito saṃvegamāpādīti.
sn9.11:4.1.eng: Impelled by that deity, that mendicant was struck with a sense of urgency.

sn9.12:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ aññataro bhikkhu kosalesu viharati aññatarasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe.
sn9.12:1.1.eng: At one time one of the mendicants was staying in the land of the Kosalans in a certain forest grove.

sn9.12:1.2.pli: Atha kho tasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe adhivatthā devatā yena so bhikkhu tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā tassa bhikkhuno santike imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn9.12:1.2.eng: The deity haunting that forest approached that mendicant and spoke this verse in their presence:

sn9.13:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ sambahulā bhikkhū kosalesu viharanti aññatarasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe uddhatā unnaḷā capalā mukharā vikiṇṇavācā muṭṭhassatino asampajānā asamāhitā vibbhantacittā pākatindriyā.
sn9.13:1.1.eng: At one time several mendicants were staying in the Kosalan lands in a certain forest grove. They were restless, insolent, fickle, scurrilous, loose-tongued, unmindful, lacking situational awareness and immersion, with straying minds and undisciplined faculties.

sn9.13:1.2.pli: Atha kho yā tasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe adhivatthā devatā tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ anukampikā atthakāmā te bhikkhū saṃvejetukāmā yena te bhikkhū tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā te bhikkhū gāthāhi ajjhabhāsi:
sn9.13:1.2.eng: The deity haunting that forest had sympathy for those mendicants, and wanted what’s best for them. So they approached those mendicants wanting to stir them up, and addressed them in verse:
sn9.13:1.2.comm: Ja 392 gives another version of this story.

sn9.13:2.5.eng: Knowing that the world was impermanent

sn9.13:2.6.eng: they made an end of suffering.

sn9.13:3.1.eng: But now they’ve made themselves hard to look after,

sn9.13:3.3.eng: They eat and eat and then lie down,

sn9.13:3.4.eng: unconscious in the homes of others.

sn9.13:4.1.eng: Having raised my joined palms to the Saṅgha,

sn9.13:4.2.eng: I speak here only about certain people.

sn9.13:4.4.eng: just like those who have passed away.

sn9.13:6.1.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū tāya devatāya saṃvejitā saṃvegamāpādunti.
sn9.13:6.1.eng: Impelled by that deity, those mendicants were struck with a sense of urgency.

sn9.14:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ aññataro bhikkhu kosalesu viharati aññatarasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe.
sn9.14:1.1.eng: At one time one of the mendicants was staying in the land of the Kosalans in a certain forest grove.

sn9.14:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena so bhikkhu pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto pokkharaṇiṃ ogāhetvā padumaṃ upasiṅghati.
sn9.14:1.2.eng: Now at that time, after the meal, on their return from almsround, that mendicant plunged into a lotus pond and sniffed a pink lotus.

sn9.14:1.3.pli: Atha kho yā tasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe adhivatthā devatā tassa bhikkhuno anukampikā atthakāmā taṃ bhikkhuṃ saṃvejetukāmā yena so bhikkhu tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā taṃ bhikkhuṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn9.14:1.3.eng: The deity haunting that forest had sympathy for that mendicant, and wanted what’s best for them. So they approached that mendicant wanting to stir them up, and addressed them in verse:

sn9.14:2.1.eng: “This water flower has not been given.

sn9.14:2.3.eng: this is one factor of theft.
sn9.14:2.3.comm: This is, of course, poetry. In the Vinaya, to be theft it must be something someone owns, and they must perceive it as taken and lost to them.

sn9.14:2.4.eng: Good fellow, you are a thief of scent!”

sn9.14:3.1.eng: “I do not take, nor do I break;

sn9.14:3.2.eng: I sniff the water flower from afar.

sn9.14:3.3.eng: So how do you explain why
sn9.14:3.3.comm: Kena vaṇṇena is used occasionally in this idiom (SN 10.2:3.1, Thig 13.4:2.3), which is apparently not attested in Sanskrit. The commentary explains vaṇṇa here as “reason” (kāraṇa). In each context, there is an apparently hidden circumstance that needs to be brought to light. I think it anticipates vaṇṇanā in the sense of “commentary”, “explanation”; cf. English “gloss”.

sn9.14:3.4.eng: you call me a thief of scent?

sn9.14:5.2.eng: to a person who is a crude vandal,

sn9.14:5.4.eng: You’re the one who deserves to be spoken to.

sn9.14:6.1.eng: To the man who has not a blemish

sn9.14:6.4.eng: seems as big as a stormcloud.”

sn9.14:7.4.eng: whenever you see something like this.”

sn9.14:8.1.comm: The deity disavows dependence on humans and any mutual obligation that may entail. They gave advice freely.

sn9.14:8.4.eng: the way that leads to a good place.”

sn9.14:9.1.pli: Atha kho so bhikkhu tāya devatāya saṃvejito saṃvegamāpādīti.
sn9.14:9.1.eng: Impelled by that deity, that mendicant was struck with a sense of urgency.

sn9.14:11.5.eng: The Linked Discourses in the Forest are completed.

sn9.2:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ aññataro bhikkhu kosalesu viharati aññatarasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe.
sn9.2:1.1.eng: At one time one of the mendicants was staying in the land of the Kosalans in a certain forest grove.

sn9.2:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena so bhikkhu divāvihāragato supati.
sn9.2:1.2.eng: Now at that time that mendicant went for the day’s meditation, but fell asleep.
sn9.2:1.2.comm: A midday nap in the heat was common (DN 23:15.2), but was considered a vice in excess (DN 31:14.14). The Buddha defended the practice, saying that he took a nap on occasion (MN 36:45.8).

sn9.2:1.3.pli: Atha kho yā tasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe adhivatthā devatā tassa bhikkhuno anukampikā atthakāmā taṃ bhikkhuṃ saṃvejetukāmā yena so bhikkhu tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā taṃ bhikkhuṃ gāthāhi ajjhabhāsi:
sn9.2:1.3.eng: The deity haunting that forest had sympathy for that mendicant, and wanted what’s best for them. So they approached that mendicant wanting to stir them up, and addressed them in verse:

sn9.2:3.2.eng: that led you to go forth

sn9.2:3.3.eng: from the home life to homelessness.

sn9.2:3.4.eng: Don’t fall under the sway of slumber.”

sn9.2:4.2.eng: but dullards still fall for them.

sn9.2:4.3.eng: Among those who are bound, <j>they’re free and unattached:

sn9.2:5.3.eng: that knowledge has been perfectly cleansed:
